title: 108_s2645
content: The Act may be cited as the "Public Broadcasting Reauthorization Act of 2004" and authorizes appropriations. The Public Broadcasting Reauthorization Act of 2004 authorizes appropriations to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, specifying amounts for fiscal years 2007 to 2011 based on non-Federal financial support received by public broadcasting entities. Authorized appropriations for the transition to digital technology and programming under the Public Broadcasting Reauthorization Act of 2004 include $50 million for fiscal year 2005, $50 million for fiscal year 2006, $40 million for fiscal year 2007, $30 million for fiscal year 2008, and $20 million for fiscal year 2009. Funds are to be disbursed by the Secretary of the Treasury for immediate use by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. Funds are to be distributed expeditiously by the Secretary of the Treasury for immediate use by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. The Secretary of the Treasury disburses funds to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting annually. Public Telecommunications Facilities Program Grants are increased for fiscal years 2005 to 2008. The Public Broadcasting Reauthorization Act of 2004 authorizes increasing funds for public broadcasting facilities and equipment, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2007 to 2011. SEC. 3. RECOUPMENT OF FUNDS BY CORPORATION. Section 396(k) of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require public broadcast stations to return unexpended funds and grants for public telecommunications services if they cease operations or transfer their broadcast license. The amendment to Section 396(k) of the Communications Act of 1934 requires public broadcast stations to return a proportionate amount of unexpended funds and grants for public telecommunications services if they cease operations or transfer their broadcast license. The Communications Act of 1934 is being amended to redefine public telecommunications services to include new technologies. This includes noncommercial educational and cultural radio and television programming, as well as instructional or informational material transmitted electronically. Additionally, there are provisions for public broadcast stations to return funds and grants if they cease operations or transfer their broadcast license. SEC. 5. LOCAL CONTENT, PROGRAMMING, AND SERVICES. Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to focus on supporting content, programming, and services that cater to the local community's needs and interests.
